info.game_comments:
1998 Boston Week game 1.
From the Wang Center for the Performing Arts in Boston, Massachusetts.

double_jeopardy_round: THIS IS YOUR LIFE, WOODROW WILSON

(1, 1).clue: The Wasatch & Oquirrh Mountains surround this Utah capital

(2, 1).clue: According to Paul Simon, 2 of them are "Slip out the back, Jack" & "Make a new plan, Stan"

(3, 1).clue: She was offered 1,100 pieces of silver from each Philistine lord for help in defeating Samson

(4, 1).clue: The Brady Bill requires a 5-day waiting period on the purchase of these

(5, 1).clue: They can be Arabica, robusta or Liberian

(6, 1).clue: A close shave means you made it out "by the skin of " these

(1, 2).clue: He was only a candidate for president when North America's tallest mountain was named for him

(2, 2).clue: This 1995-96 hit by Mariah Carey & Boyz II Men holds the record for the most weeks at No. 1 with 16

(3, 2).clue: When David first saw her, she was "washing herself, and" she "was very beautiful to look upon"

(4, 2).clue: Unlike his horse, his sidekick Pat Brady isn't mounted for display at his museum

(5, 2).clue: It's the enumerative slang for an accountant or other financial exec

(6, 2).clue: When you "jump down" another person's, you may see some words that got stuck there

(1, 3).clue: The view from the top of this Colorado peak inspired the words to "America The Beautiful"

(2, 3).clue: Tony Orlando & Dawn sang, do this "on the ceiling if you want me, twice on the pipe if the answer is no"

(3, 3).clue: The Lord told Ahab, "The dogs shall eat" her "by the wall of Jezreel"

(4, 3).clue: From 1988 to 1993 Nicholas Brady was Secretary of this, so he was always on the money

(5, 3).clue: Born Dallas Burroughs in 1928, he's the actor seen here

(6, 3).clue: It's what a guy is "twisted around" by a girl who can get him to do anything

(1, 4).clue: In 1829 Johann Jacob von Parrot climbed this mountain but didn't find Noah's Ark

(2, 4).clue: In this 1955 hit Tennessee Ernie Ford owed his "soul to the company store"

(3, 4).clue: She looked back at Sodom & Gomorrah & "became a pillar of salt"

(4, 4).clue: Sources list him as the official photographer of the Civil War

(5, 4).clue: These crisp edible shoots of germinated beans like mung are popular in Chinese cooking

(6, 4).clue: A nit-picker might "split" them & a monster might make them "stand on end"

(1, 5).clue: Tacoma's name was derived from Tahoma, an Indian name for this mountain

(2, 5).clue: In September 1996 "The Drew Carey Show" began using a dance routine to this Vogues hit as its opening theme

(3, 5).clue: When told she was going to have a child by Abraham, she "laughed within herself"

(4, 5).clue: The Urological Institute at Johns Hopkins came about through an endowment by this flashy 19th c. financier

(5, 5).clue: These beans resemble the human internal organs with which they share their name

(6, 5).clue: An old proverb says "Many" these "make light work"

(1, 1).clue: The Brahmins are at the top of this hierarchical "system" most associated with India

(2, 1).clue: Eliot Ness was born in this city, where he would later rise to crimefighting fame

(3, 1).clue: Part of this sitcom's 100th episode, aired Nov. 11, 1997, was shot on location in Seattle

(5, 1).clue: We bet you never called this second wife "Dingbat"; pucker up for....

(1, 2).clue: Brahmins who worship Vishnu practice this dietary habit, like George Bernard Shaw

(2, 2).clue: The Untouchables were formed to harass this mobster kingpin

(3, 2).clue: (VIDEO DAILY DOUBLE):"(Hi, I'm Jason Alexander)  This actor co-starred with me on a sitcom called "E/R" before starring on the medical series "ER" "

(5, 2).clue: How about a game of "Black Jack" with this man you put in charge of U.S. forces in Europe?  Yes, it's....

(1, 3).clue: "Brahmin" originally meant "prayer" in this ancient Hindu language

(2, 3).clue: "Wallpaper" Wolff, the last surviving Untouchable, helped this actor prepare to play Eliot Ness in the 1987 film

(3, 3).clue: In May 1998 the final episode of this sitcom featured Julia Roberts falling for Frank Fontana

(5, 3).clue: This foreign general ticked you off when he raided Columbus, New Mexico in 1916; Bienvenido a.....

(1, 4).clue: This Brahmin who became India's first prime minister was called Pandit, or "teacher"

(2, 4).clue: Eliot Ness was hired by the Prohibition bureau in 1929, the same year as this holiday bloodletting

(3, 4).clue: Sam Neill played this whiz of a wizard in a 1998 miniseries

(5, 4).clue: No hard feelings, though this Socialist was only released from prison by your successor; welcome....

(1, 5).clue: Traditionally, Brahmins are devoted to the study of these books, like the Atharva- & the Rig-

(2, 5).clue: The Untouchables cooperated with this government agency by providing confiscated mob account books

(3, 5).clue: This star of "Webster" was 16 years old when the series ended its 4-year run in 1987

(4, 5).clue: The Jackson administration,the Fillmore administration,the Buchanan administration

(5, 5).clue: Who could forget this VP's line about the country needing a good 5-cent cigar?  Say hi to....

(0, 0).clue: This city was once known as Dong Kinh & to Europeans as Tonquin
